{{also|auf-}} ==English== ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|en|oaf}} * {{l|en|ouph}} * {{l|en|ouphe}} ===Etymology=== From {{etyl|enm|en}} {{m|ang|auph}}, {{m|ang|aulf}}, from {{etyl|non|en}}. See {{m|en|elf}}. ===Noun=== {{en-noun}} # {{lb|en|obsolete}} A [[changeling]] or [[elf]] [[child]]; a child left by [[fairy|fairies]]. # {{lb|en|obsolete}} A [[deformed]] or [[foolish]] child; a [[simpleton]]; an [[oaf]]. #: {{rfquotek|en|Drayton}} {{Webster 1913}} ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=afu|AFU|UAF|Ufa}} ---- ==German== ===Alternative forms=== * {{alter|de|auff}} {{qualifier|obsolete}} * {{alter|de|uf|uff}} {{qualifier|obsolete or dialectal}} ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|gmh|ūf}}, from {{inh|de|goh|ūf}}, from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*upp}}. This form with a lengthened vowel is originally [[Upper German]]. [[Central German]] forms were {{cog|gmh|uf}} and (western) {{m|gmh|up}}. Compare {{cog|lb|op}}, {{cog|nl|op}}, {{cog|en|up}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/aʊ̯f/}} * {{audio|de|De-auf.ogg|audio}} * {{rhymes|de|aʊ̯f}} ===Preposition=== {{de-prep|with dative or accusative}} # {{lb|de|with dative}} [[on]], [[upon]] {{gloss|positioned at the top of}} #: {{ux|de|Das Buch liegt '''auf''' dem Tisch.|The book is lying '''on''' the table.}} # {{lb|de|with accusative}} [[on]], [[onto]], [[up]] {{gloss|moving to the top of}} #: {{ux|de|Ich lege das Buch '''auf''' den Tisch.|I’m putting the book '''on''' the table.}} # {{lb|de|with dative}} [[in]], [[at]]; {{non-gloss definition|used with certain nouns intead of {{m|de|bei}} or {{m|de|in}}}} #: {{ux|de|'''auf''' der Kirmes|'''at''' the fun fair|inline=1}} #: {{ux|de|'''auf''' der Post|'''at''' the post office (''also:'' bei der Post)|inline=1}} # {{lb|de|with accusative}} [[to]]; {{non-gloss definition|used with certain nouns instead of {{m|de|zu}} or {{m|de|in}}}} #: {{ux|de|'''auf''' die Kirmes|'''to''' the fun fair|inline=1}} #: {{ux|de|'''auf''' die Post|'''to''' the post office (''also:'' zur Post)|inline=1}} # {{lb|de|with a language name}} [[in]] (see usage note below) #: {{ux|de|Was heißt das '''auf''' Deutsch?|What’s this '''in''' German?}} # {{lb|de|archaic|or|colloquial|regional|northern and western Germany}} [[on]] (a day; usually of the week) #: {{ux|de|Du kannst doch '''auf''' (’n) Sonntag nich’ den Rasen mähen!|You can’t mow the lawn '''on''' a Sunday!}} ====Usage notes==== * {{m|de||Auf}} is a {{m|de|Wechselpräposition}}, meaning that it is used with accusative case when the verb shows movement from one place to another, whereas it is used with dative case when the verb shows location. In idiomatic combinations with verbs the correct case is not always predictable and must be memorised. * Generally speaking, {{m|de||auf}} is used when referring to something being on a horizontal surface, as opposed to {{m|de|an}}, which usually points to a vertical surface. * {{m|de||Auf}} is used with language names not preceded by any determiners or adjectives; otherwise {{m|de|in}} is used. Thus you say something {{m|de||auf Englisch|t=in English}}, but {{m|de||in gutem Englisch|t=in good English}}. The phrase {{m|de||auf gutem Englisch}} may not be entirely ungrammatical, but it is doubtful and at most informally acceptable. ====Synonyms==== * {{sense|on a day}} {{l|de|an}} ====Derived terms==== * ('''''auf''' + das'') {{l|de|aufs}} {{q|standard}} * ('''''auf''' + dem'') {{l|de|aufm}} {{q|colloquial only}} ===Adverb=== {{de-adv}} # {{lb|de|somewhat|informal}} [[open]] #: {{syn|de|offen}} #: {{uxi|de|Die Tür ist '''auf'''.|The door is '''open'''.}} # {{lb|de|colloquial}} [[finished]]; [[gone]] {{gloss|food}} #: {{syn|de|alle}} #: {{uxi|en|Hast du deine Suppe '''auf'''?|Have you '''finished''' your soup?}} #: {{uxi|de|Die Milch is’ '''auf'''.|The milk is '''gone'''. (consumed)}} ====Usage notes==== * Compare to the latter example the phrase: ''Die Milch ist'' {{m|de|aus}}, which would mean that all the milk has been sold out, e.g. from a supermarket. ===Interjection=== {{de-interj}} # [[carry on]] {{gloss|continue or proceed as before}} # [[have a go]]
